I’ve been a little quiet on Instagram lately - regrouping and regathering after a busy online teaching season. 

In fallow times I always find it so useful to take an art course. It really helps to get the creative juices flowing again. 

Last weekend’s etching workshop with @evelynpolk was just the ticket 🤍

Inspired by the spiral vibe currently weaving it’s way through Instagram, courtesy of @adamwilliamsonart’s wonderful course, I took along a beautiful ammonite fossil, a gift from my brother (swipe ➡️ to see). 

It was really tricky having to think in reverse when building the design! But I’m very happy with the outcome. 

Here’s my finished etching plate catching the light…

#geometry #symmetry #spiral #fossil #spiralart #etching #natureandart #ecoart #naturegeometry #ammonite

Day 1 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld - the fun annual challenge organised by @taraleaver. 

Today’s prompt is: a favourite painting…

I’ve chosen this mixed media work from last year’s #100DaysExploringProcess challenge (swipe to see more pics). 

This piece means a great deal to me. I learnt so many new skills in the making of it: how to stretch watercolour paper on stretcher bars, how to use gold leaf size (glue) in a compass with a ruling pen, how to plan and execute a large expanse of geometric hand stitching, and how to frame a painting on canvas. At that point in time, it was the biggest painting I’d ever tackled, and I’m so pleased with how it turned out! 

The stitched Asanoha pattern adds a delicate, tactile element to the painting - it’s as if you feel the piece, as well as see it. And the gold leaf seed of life is so shiny! I also enjoy how the Asanoha pattern escapes the confines of the seed of life, breaking out from its starting point.

Day 2 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld

Today’s prompt is: a lesson learned…

I’ve returned to last year’s #100DaysExploringProcess challenge for this prompt too. 

As well as using the challenge as an opportunity to try out lots of new substrates and art materials, I also decided to try working on a series of paintings all at once.  It was the first time I’d tried this method, and I learned that it’s a really cool thing to do! 

The reasons it’s a great way to work are several. Some key takeaways:

- You can batch practical tasks and get them done more efficiently, e.g. stretching several canvases at once 
- If motivation is lacking, there’s always at least one painting you feel you can work on
- Paintings influence each other - ideas you have for one painting can then be used and developed in another
- Your paintings cohere well; they have a similar style and colour palette, and form a ‘collection’

Definitely something I’d recommend trying! 

Check out the #100DaysExploringProcess hashtag to see my process documented.

Day 4 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: art book…

I have a bit of an obsession with the seed of life motif, and all the sixfold loveliness that arises from it, so purchasing this beautiful #geometherapy book by @theartofprocess was a no brainer! 

Mastering The Art of Six is a book of diagrams for 22 different patterns arising from the natural division of the circle into six. It’s filled with images of Stephanie’s gorgeous renderings of the patterns. A treasure! 

I love it so much I’m thinking of using it as the sourcebook from my next 100 Day Project, which will be starting in late February - join me! 

I’ve also included a few shelfies of my growing collection of art reference books for you to browse - so many books, so little time!

Day 5 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: favourite tool…

I must confess, I’m recycling this photo from the same time last year! But, thinking about it, my favourite tools are still the same. They’re like old friends 🧡

From the back: 

1. My tuning fork which I use to centre and calm myself before starting work.

2. My little magnifying glass which I use when I’m constructing, to help with the accurate placement of my compass point.

3. My 0.3mm Zebra Drafix mechanical pencil - no sharpening required!

4. My Tombow Mono Zero eraser for precise erasing.

5. My gorgeous Haff compass - it’s true what they say about German engineering!👌

6. My little Rotring compass with ruling pen attachment - I use it for applying masking fluid. 

Looking forward to seeing other artists’ tools and picking up some recommendations 🖊🖌🖋🖍

Day 6 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: current challenge…

Oh my goodness me, I’m in full on procrastination mode with this one! 

My current challenge is to create my first Skillshare class. The theme will be stitching a geometric motif on watercolour paper, a technique I get asked about often.

I’ve created the exemplars, taken some pretty photos, tidied up the studio and created a calm, uncluttered backdrop for my ‘talking head’ shots - and now I’ve just got to film it! 

For some reason I’m putting this stage off - why?! I think I’m daunted by all the new skills I need to learn: lighting, sound, filming and of course, editing…

However, I had a great #lkbpeergroup chat yesterday and I’m feeling much more confident and motivated. It WILL happen!

Day 8 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: my inspiration…

Nature is a fantastic source of pattern inspiration and I really enjoy incorporating natural elements into my geometric artworks. 

‘Li’ is a Chinese concept for the unregimented, ever-changing pattern found in the natural world, whose organising principle is essentially mathematical. 

I think I’m drawn to the gentle elegance of line and form in the natural world, and love how this contrasts and interacts with the proportional harmonies inherent in geometric structures. There's something about the interplay of symmetry and asymmetry, order and chaos, rigidity and freedom that hints at a truth held just out of reach.

Swipe ➡️ to see the full images…

Day 11 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: turning point…

I’m going right back to some of the first posts on my Instagram account for this one! Back to October 2019 when I participated in my first Inktober with #InktoberAlhambra. 

I took on the challenge of completing the 43 patterns from the wonderful book ‘The Alhambra With A Ruler And Compass’ by @manuel_martinez_vela. 

This first hashtag challenge was a real turning point for me. It was my first experience of committing to a period of daily art-making and of bravely posting it publicly, and it was such a great experience! Exhausting, but exhilarating! And I developed my practice so much over the course of that month. 

I now tackle hashtag challenges regularly throughout the year, and find them a fantastic vehicle for focusing in on an aspect of my art practice that I wish to explore and develop.

This year I’m hoping to take part in #The100DayProject again, and perhaps also #SketchADayJune and #Inktober later in the year.

I also enjoy the ‘meet the artist’ type of hashtag challenge, like this one I’m posting in right now! There’s also #AugustForArtists which I’ve done before and #MarchMeetTheMaker, which I’d like to try one day. 

Honestly, get involved in a hashtag challenge - they’re great!

Day 12 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: current motif…

One thing I keep coming back to in my work is the golden ratio (phi) and its associated motifs: the golden spiral and the pentagram. 

It’s just such a clever relationship! And it appears all around us as Nature’s fractal packaging ratio, arranging seeds on seed heads, petals around flower heads and leaves on stems 🌸🌿

Swipe ➡️ to see more of my work exploring this proportion. You’ll also spot my golden ratio callipers, which reveal the ratio’s presence in the structure of the patterns! 

I don’t just use the golden ratio to construct motifs, I also use it as a proportional guide when thinking about both how to size and where to place my motifs on the page. It always seems to lead to a pleasing composition - who knows!

I have even developed a popular online geometric art course based around the golden ratio and its associated patterns: Golden Geometry, which is returning for probably its last live run later this year. 

You can check out some of the fantastic student work on this hashtag: #GoldenGeometryCG 

And you can see my current course offering via the link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art

Courses are suitable for beginners, and you receive lifetime access to the session recordings, so you don’t have to attend live. And all videos are subtitled 👍

Perhaps see you online sometime soon 😊

Day 15 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: how I name my paintings…

I must confess, I often take the ‘say what you see’ approach. For example, this one is called “Cow parsley with a double seed of life”! 

However, for my first 100 Days project where I needed come up with 100 names in 100 days, I just went with one-word titles. Names often occurred to me while working on the paintings themselves - something would just pop into my head. It might be that the painting reminded me of something visually, or that I felt it was symbolic in some way. 

For example, swipe ➡️ to see
1. Shell
2. Path
3. Velvet

How do you name your paintings?

16 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: smallest painting…

My smallest paintings are 100 in number! Each a 6.5cm diameter circle, completed as part of the #The100DayProject I undertook in 2021, my #100DaysOfCircleGeometry. 

It was during this project that I first started experimenting with stitching paper, and for this painting I learnt how to create an ellipse from straight lines - how cool!

I love it because it it reminds me of a view onto trees reflected in a pond - indeed it’s titled ‘View’. 

🌳🌳🌳

If you are interested in learning geometric paper embroidery, then you’ll be pleased to hear I’m currently filming my first Skillshare class on just that topic! Do sign up to my newsletter to be informed when it’s published 🎥

Day 17 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: largest painting…

It’s another stitched one! This is my largest painting at 50 x 70 cm: watercolour, gold leaf and gold thread on watercolour paper, mounted on stretcher bars. Painted as part of last year’s #100DaysExploringProcess series. 

It’s such a great surface to work on - I must do it again! 

The seed of life motif is positioned using the golden ratio. And the sixfold #Islamicpattern pattern arises from this seed of life and escapes its boundaries, spreading haphazardly across the surface. 

Many hours of stitching were needed to finish this one! 

Swipe to see some close ups and a photo of the painting exhibited at the Aperiodic Tilings Mathematical Art exhibition at @theopenuniversity last year. 

If you are interested in learning geometric paper embroidery, then you’ll be pleased to hear I’m currently filming my first Skillshare class on just that topic! Do sign up to my newsletter to be informed when it’s published 🎥

Day 20 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: favourite technique…

I couldn’t make my mind up about this one! 

Is my favourite technique using my trusty gold pens? Or is it stitching with gold thread? I couldn’t decide, so I’ve chosen both! 

I think the common thread (see what I did there?) is the addition of gold, in whatever form!

Although my personal style is quite simple and muted, a hidden bling side seems to emerge in my artwork! 

Gold adds an immediate touch of elegance and delicacy that I love. 

Bring on the gold! 

These are all paintings from the 2021#geometrysketchbook challenge. All works are now sold. I’ll be restocking my Etsy shop in a a couple of months’ time - sign up to my newsletter to hear more!

Day 21 of #21DaysInMyArtWorld: big dream!

I’ve chosen an image of a Ganesh Yantra decorated with silver leaf, that I constructed under Daniel’s calm tutelage at @sacredartofgeometry studio. 

This yantra is symbolic of overcoming obstacles and achieving success, so here goes! 

My big dream for this year, and onwards, is to create ‘on-demand’ video courses, which students can access anytime, and work through at their own pace. 

The reasons for wanting to move slowly away from the live Zoom sessions is two-fold. 

Firstly it means students can start a course at any point in the year, and don’t need to wait for the live sessions.

And secondly, and perhaps more importantly, rather than re-running live courses again each year, I will have the time to create NEW courses, which is something I really love to do! 

I’m considering establishing a Facebook group, or something similar, to maintain a sense of community, and so that I can continue to give encouragement and answer queries, much as I do now. 

And I’m planning to trial some of the new courses ‘live’ first, before converting them to video courses, so we will still have the opportunity to connect online on Zoom at various points in the year. 

I am currently in the process of filming and editing my first short course to be hosted on Skillshare, and this has revealed to me what a HUGE amount of work there is in creating these pre-recorded classes. But I remain excited by the possibilities. 

What do you think?!

Less than a week to go until my Introduction to Geometric Art online course comes around again!

Swipe to see some STUNNING artwork from previous participants 😍

It starts on the 11th February so there’s still time to sign up - the link is in my bio @clarissagrandi.art ⬅️

I’ve designed the course to be accessible to complete beginners. 

Choose to attend the live sessions or work from the class recordings at your own pace.

You will be introduced to various forms of geometric design, including Islamic geometric patterns, the golden ratio and Gothic tracery. 

We will also explore ways of decorating and colouring our patterns. 

Session 1: Mandalas with circles

Session 2: Sixfold Alhambra patterns hiding in the 'flower of life'

Session 3: Fivefold symmetry and the Golden Ratio

Session 4: Fourfold Islamic patterns that tessellate in squares

Session 5: Gothic tracery and the trefoil window

All sessions are recorded and shared within 48 hours, with lifetime access, so there’s no need to attend the live Zoom sessions if the timings are inconvenient. 

And all videos contain subtitles 👍

I spent such an enjoyable morning yesterday exploring the beginnings of six-fold geometry with the new #ITGAcourse cohort - great fun! 

So it feels like a good time to announce my plans for this year’s #the100DayProject in which I’ll be focusing on the beauty of sixes!

The project starts on 22nd February, and I’m planning to work through the fantastically inspiring #geometherapy book, Mastering the Art of Six, by Stephanie @theartofprocess. It’s a treasure 💛

I’m drawn again and again to the seed of life in my own work, so I’m very much looking forward to taking this journey through some new six-fold patterns. 

Pictured is one of the stunning patterns from the book, taught online by Stephanie a couple of weeks ago. Swipe to see some images of the book.

Exciting! If you’d like to join me, please use the hashtag #100DaysOfGeometherapy. 

And remember, while the aim is to build in some creative practice each day for 100 days, it’s fine to post photos of work in progress, and also to take rest days. Life will get in the way at times, and you’ll have more chance of lasting the course if you put your perfectionism to one side (difficult for us arty types, I know!) and forgive yourself for missing a day (or a few)!

D A Y  1 ~ A gentle start to this year’s #the100DayProject, inspired by the beautiful @geometherapy book, Mastering the Art of Six, by Stephanie @theartofprocess.

The first days of the project for me are always about gathering my materials & clarifying my focus. 

I always find it useful to restrict myself to certain materials & colour palettes - it helps enormously with decision making.

As well as using Stephanie’s book, I am keen to explore the concept of ‘Li’ when decorating my work. My reference will be this lovely little @woodenbooks by @dav.d_wade: Li: Dynamic Form in Nature. 

As a result, I think my colour scheme is going to be naturals: warm earthy tones, splashes of greens and blues, perhaps a dash of pink 💕 (for fun!) and of course, some shiny golds and coppers 🤩

In terms of materials, I’m keen to explore some of the following: 

🖊️ My new @copic_official_uk sepia multiliners 
✒️ My growing set of @rohrerundklingner_official inks 
🖌️ And I might not be able to keep my hands off my @roman_szmal_art watercolours! Hello again, Aquarius Green! 
💛 Then, of course, there’ll be some metallic pen! My favourites are my @uni_official_kr PX-203 markers, my @pebeo_uk Pebeo4Artists markers and my @sakura_europe PenTouch markers. 
🌟Plus some metallic copper and gold leaf! 

Finally my substrates: 
 📝 I’m looking forward to working on my @clairefontaineuk PaintOn paper - I love the colours! 🖤 And I’ve been gifted some of their black Etival watercolour paper - excited to try it out! 
🪵 I’m also keen to try working on these @jacksons_art wooden panels which I’ll be coating in @danielsmithartistsmaterials watercolour ground - it comes in transparent, gold and black! 

I’m so looking forward to building in some daily creative practice 🧡

If you have Stephanie’s book and would like to join in, use the hashtag #100DaysOfGeometherapy. Or perhaps join in with a theme of your own 🌸

D A Y  4 ~ results are in! …

So… the Schminke Aqua Bronze didn’t adhere well to the bare wood panel. Most of it seems to have fallen off! I might try adding some gum Arabic next time. 

But, I think I’m rather liking the result - it’s gives it an aged look I am drawn to. 

And I like the way the inks have dried. Muted, like moss, with some glints of gold. 

I took my stencil to the surface and removed some pigment, leaving a very faint hexagonal imprint. It is a sixfold challenge after all!

All in all, interesting results. I’m going to leave this one for a bit and see what it calls for next…

Would you like to learn how to construct ancient spiral and labyrinth patterns with a compass and ruler? 🌀🌀🌀

My new four-session online course: Spirals and Labyrinths, starts on Saturday 1st April.

If you can’t attend live, recordings will be available for playback anytime.

We'll start by constructing geometric versions of prehistoric spiral motifs, including the triskele carving at Newgrange passage tomb. 

Over the next sessions we'll then journey forward through time, drawing classical Cretan labyrinths, an Indian spiral labyrinth, and the labyrinths found in Medieval Gothic cathedrals, including the famous Chartres pavement labyrinth. 

We'll finish with a beautiful contemporary design based on the vesica piscis. 

Swipe to see participant feedback and stunning artwork from last year’s students. 

Click the link to learn more and book your place ⬆️

Please note, there is no requirement to attend the live Zoom sessions if the timings are inconvenient. All sessions are recorded and shared with lifetime access, so that you can complete the course at a time and pace that suits you. Subtitles are available.

Perhaps see you online soon!

Thrilled to be teaming up with Stephanie @theartofprocess for another two-day geometry workshop! 

This time we’ll lead you through the construction and ornamentation of this STUNNING 15th Century floor mosaic from the Basilica San Marco in Venice.

On Saturday, I will teach the construction of the outer square frame and the geometrical composition at the centre: a small stellated dodecahedron encircled in a ring of hexagonal prisms.

On Sunday, Stephanie will turn our attention to the ornate biomorphic elements that frame the geometric centre.

Finally, there will be time to discuss some different ideas for rendering your mosaic drawing and bringing it to life. 

So excited about this one!

Course dates: 13th and 14th May, 9:30am GMT+1 London time.

Learn more and sign up via the link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art

My first ever #Skillshare class, Geometric Paper Embroidery, is now a Staff Pick! 

With nearly 250 students signed up already, and fifteen 100% positive reviews to boot, it’s been a whirlwind adventure, and I’m so excited to begin filming the follow-up class soon 😀

This video explains what to expect from the class, and there’s a link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art entitling you to a FREE month of Skillshare access. 

So, after you’ve watched my class, be sure to check out lots of other interesting classes too! 

In this class you’ll learn:
~ How to construct a simple geometric motif with compass and ruler
~ Tips on achieving accuracy in your geometric designs
~ How to choose your colour palette
~ Which threads and paper types are suitable for paper stitching
~ How to pierce and prepare your paper for stitching
~ How to plan your stitching sequence
~ And how to tighten and secure your stitches to finish your artwork

You’ll be creating an elegant, hand-stitched geometric artwork you’ll be proud to display or gift.

Don’t delay, learn a new skill today!

So excited to be teaming up with Stephanie @theartofprocess for another two-day geometry workshop THIS COMING WEEKEND! 

We’ll be guiding you through the construction and ornamentation of this STUNNING 15th Century floor mosaic from the Basilica San Marco in Venice.

On Saturday, I will teach the construction of the outer square frame and the geometrical composition at the centre: a small stellated dodecahedron encircled in a ring of hexagonal prisms.

On Sunday, Stephanie will turn our attention to the ornate biomorphic elements that frame the geometric centre.

Finally, there will be time to discuss some different ideas for rendering your mosaic drawing and bringing it to life. 

Course dates: 13th and 14th May, 9:30am GMT+1 London time.

Course cost: $67.50 AUD 

We’ll be working BIG (on A2 paper or similar) so an 18 inch ruler would be useful (but not essential). 

Learn more and sign up via the link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art

***Please note, there is no requirement to attend the live Zoom sessions if the timings are inconvenient. All sessions are recorded for playback anytime.***

Trying out my new toy (swipe) on a 64 circle torus, and I’m seriously impressed with the level of accuracy it’s helped me to achieve!

My first digital watercolour!

The last few weeks I’ve been in what @taraleaver describes as an ‘afterslump’: that period of low inspiration and energy that sometimes follows an intense creative period. 

It often happens to me after finishing a hashtag challenge, and one of the best ways I’ve found to get back in the swing again, is to engage in a creative class and learn something new. 

@sandy.kurt’s new ‘Procreate for Islamic Geometric Patterns’ #sandykurtcourse has been just what I needed! 

The last few days I’ve been totally immersed in my happy place, and I’m so pleased with what I have learnt to do. 

I’ve wanted to learn Procreate for a long time, but never before found a tutorial that has properly covered what’s needed for geometric art, until now…

Thank you, Sandy! I’m so looking forward to experimenting with my newfound skills.

Exciting announcement for 2024! 

I’m delighted to be collaborating with Basia and Bertrand of @flores.del.camino to offer an 8-day retreat in Spain in July 2024: "Sacred Windows - Creativity & Presence".

The theme will be about taking the time and space to engage with the creative practice of sacred geometry as a mindful and contemplative act. 

Our inspiration will be the rose windows of the Camino de Santiago, with a specific focus on the majestic windows of Leon Cathedral.

Bertrand will be tapping into his considerable knowledge of the geometry of Gothic arch and window design to lead us through the ruler and compass constructions of some of these windows.

Basia will guide us skilfully through the mindful and contemplative aspects of the retreat, and will also be sharing her knowledge of collecting, preparing and painting with the foraged earthen pigments that she uses in her own creative practice.

My role will be to introduce participants to a range of additional materials and techniques with which to decorate our windows. 

Amongst other things I’ll be teaching how to render tracery to achieve a 3D effect, how to use and apply gold leaf in various ways, how to infill your windows with different ‘stained glass’ effects, and how to use paper embroidery to enhance and elevate your designs.

I am SO excited!

Flores are offering a complimentary box of 20 ready-prepared earth pigments and exquisite rose window colouring book, worth €80, to those who sign up to the retreat. 

You can see me unboxing a slightly larger set of pigments in a recent reel.

If you would like to take advantage of this offer, please use the following ‘discount’ code at checkout:  SW24CG

It will show as a discount of €1, but will entitle you to your set of pigments when you arrive at the retreat centre. 

You can find further details about the retreat on the link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art and you can book with the ‘early bird’ price until December 31st 2023.

Perhaps see you in sunny Spain next year! ☀️

Would you like to learn how to draw these stunning medieval church floor designs using just a ruler and compass? 

Join me online for this four-session course starting Saturday 29th July, 10am BST (London time)!

Dates not convenient? Can’t attend the live sessions? No problem! All the recordings will be shared with you for playback anytime.

We'll start by looking at a selection of geometric ‘trompe l'oeil’ patterns that tile in squares and hexagons. 

And then we’ll spend the final two sessions working on two stunning radial circular designs. 

You’ll have the option of working on simplified versions of these, which are more suitable for less experienced geometers. Or if you’re feeling confident, you can draw the full versions instead!

We will also touch on some different techniques for decorating your finished patterns, including how to trace, transfer and tile repeating patterns, and various ways of adding colour.

I've had the best time planning this course, and I’m just SO excited to share what I’ve learnt!

Swipe to see some more of the patterns we’ll be drawing and some lovely testimonials from participants of previous courses.

I’m in the midst of filming and editing my next Skillshare class, so I thought I’d share this little reminder about my first class, Geometric Paper Embroidery. 

In the class I walk you through the whole process of constructing, colouring and embroidering a little seed of life pattern on watercolour paper. 

There’s lots of lovely student work to see in the class gallery, and I’m proud to share that the class earned a coveted ’Staff Pick’ badge and has 100% positive reviews 😃

If you sign up to the class via the link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art (third one down in my Linktree) then you get a whole free month of Skillshare to enjoy. There’s so much good stuff on there for creatives! 

Right, I’d better get back to it - publishing deadline one week from now 😅

So excited to have published my new @skillshare class: Construct and Colour a Geometric Mandala of Spiralling Squares! 

You’ll find the link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art and it comes with a FREE, month-long Skillshare trial. 

So, after you’ve watched my class, be sure to check out lots of other interesting classes too! 

In this class you’ll learn:
• How to construct a simple geometric pattern - the double seed of life - with compass and ruler
• Tips on achieving accuracy in your geometric designs
• Ideas for how to decorate and colour this first pattern
• How to use the first pattern to create the second: a mandala of spiralling squares 
• Ideas for how to decorate and colour this second pattern, including a demonstration of a two-tone watercolour painting technique that is a favourite of mine.

You’ll be creating two stunning patterns to decorate with your preferred media 🎨🖌️🖍️🖊️

Don’t delay, learn a new skill today!

I’ve been very quiet on Instagram the last few weeks, enjoying some much needed downtime. 

But something exciting is coming soon…
 
I am happy to announce that I will be participating in this year’s Making Zen Retreat, hosted by @zenstitching!
 
What’s Making Zen? 

It’s a FREE 5-day online retreat for stitchers and crafters where you can learn new processes, improve technique, and get inspired. 

It’s happening September 25-29, and there will be workshops from about 20 different presenters, including mine on Parabolic Paper Stitching!
 
This retreat is going to be loads of fun, and a great way to improve your craft or learn a new one. 

If you want to join in, just head over to the link in my bio @clarissagrandi.art to get your ticket for free!

A few of weeks ago I treated myself to the Mandalas of the World course with @sacredartofgeometry. Truly a soul nourishing experience! 

Five wonderful days spent in great company and under Daniel’s calm and knowledgeable guidance. Always a pleasure, Daniel! 

This is one of the patterns we drew together. I’ve drawn it many times before (and have a Skillshare tutorial on it too: spiralling squares) but this time I tried something different and am adding these little ‘leaf’ motifs - love it! 🤎🌿🌟 

Do check out Vija’s rendering of the same pattern on the @sacredartofgeometry page - it’s stunning! 

I’ve got a few other patterns from the course to work on - looking forward to sharing them soon.

D A Y  1 🖋️ The nights are drawing in, and Autumn 🍂 is on its way, which can only mean one thing: #Inktober! And, lucky me, I have a copy of Ameet @ambigraph Hindocha’s wonderful new #12TwelvesRadian book to guide me through it this year 🙏💙🙏

I’ve spent a little bit of time this morning, gathering my materials and thinking through my restricted colour palette 🎨 

I think I’m going to go for a @williammorrissocietyuk vibe: all rusts and blush pinks with olive and sage greens, and a li’l dash of indigo blue 🧡🌸🌿🧵🪡

I’m looking forward to playing with my @rohrerundklingner_official inks, my gold paints and pens, and perhaps a little bit of gold leaf too 🌟 Plus, I’m really keen to add some #paperstitching 📜🧵🪡

I’m hoping to post daily, but will forgive myself if I don’t. I’m just looking forward to getting back out into the studio and enjoying the restorative, healing power of artmaking again 🌸

Not really got any more detailed plans than that. Luckily, I’ll always be able to make a start using the patterns in the book. I’m looking forward to seeing where they take me…

Will I complete all twelve?! 😃

Fellow geometry lovers, join me! Use #geoinktober and if you use Ameet’s book, #12TwelvesRadian, when you share your work, and we’ll all be able to find it in one place 😊

~ Would you like to learn how to create beautiful works of geometric art? 

~ Join me for the Circles online course, where I’ll be guiding you through the whole process. 

~ We’ll be constructing and decorating elegant curved patterns built from layers of overlapping circular arcs.

~ Designed to be suitable for beginner and intermediate geometers alike, the course starts on Saturday 4th November, 2pm GMT (London time)🕑 

~ Choose to attend the live sessions or simply work from the class recordings at your own pace 🗓

~ Over the four sessions we will be exploring a mix of historic and contemporary designs, including some found in Roman mosaics, Celtic art, Islamic tiling and Gothic architecture ⛪️🕌🏛

~ We will also touch on some different techniques for decorating your finished patterns: how to trace and transfer a repeat pattern, how to create a woven, interleaved outline, and how to experiment with watercolours 🖌🎨

~ Swipe to see stunning artwork from previous Circles students, as well as some participant feedback 💬

~ Click the link (or visit my bio @clarissagrandi.art) to learn more and sign up! 🖋 (NB if you don’t see the option to purchase a ticket, try opening Eventbrite in your browser, instead of the iPhone app). 

***Please note, there is no requirement to attend the live sessions. Everything is recorded so that you can complete the course at a time and pace that suits you***

***All videos include subtitles***

Perhaps see you online soon 🤗

D A Y  1: A favourite painting 🖌️

This will be my third year taking part in @taraleaver’s #21DaysInMyArtWorld. It’s such an enjoyable challenge and provides a lovely way to connect with followers old and new at the start of each year. It’s not too late to join in!

I’ve chosen this ‘forest cathedral’ as my favourite painting. I remember thoroughly enjoying the process of making this one. 

I was inspired by a photo of the elegant arched window at Askeaton Friary (swipe ➡️ to see it). The original has five arches, and I simplified mine to three, but the basic construction is the same.

Then, I happened across @nellekepieters gorgeous forest photos, and the idea for this painting was born: a gothic forest arch!

I exposed and highlighted the underlying construction in gold, because it’s just so darn beautiful!

Then one of the naughty crows took flight and broke the symmetry… 🐦‍⬛🌳🐦‍⬛

If you are interested in learning more about the geometry behind Gothic design, you might enjoy my Medieval Church Geometry Zoom workshop taking place on Sunday 28th Jan. The link with further information is in my bio @clarissagrandi.art 🔗👈

D A Y  2: A lesson learned.

“You must do the thing you think you cannot do.” Eleanor Roosevelt. 

This time last year I was grappling with what felt like an insurmountable challenge: filming and editing my first pre-recorded video class. 

I had no idea how to do any of it: setting up for filming, recording audio, scripting, and the big one, editing video. No idea whatsoever! 

I was lucky enough to have two fantastic sources of support, and can honestly say that I could not have done it without them! 

Firstly, I’d taken @lizkohlerbrown’s excellent Class Creation workshop, and was lucky enough to be part of a super-supportive peer group as a result. You know who you are, @kari.barnes.art @jamsolutions @kiiingcodesigns @livingroomquiltstudio and @stephanie_reiss_kelly 🙏

And, secondly, I was accepted onto Skillshare’s Teach Challenge where I had access to an excellent coaching program. 

Baby steps all the way, lots of disasters, backward steps, (and a great deal of swearing on the cutting room floor!) and I made it! 

My first Skillshare class: Geometric Paper Embroidery, was published in March last year, and I’ve since created three more! 

One, the Triskele class, is available on YouTube, and the other three are accessible via a one month Skillshare free trial. You can find all the links in my bio @clarissagrandi.art 🔗👈

Small creative business owners, in a fast-changing world, need to learn new skills all the time. One thing I learnt from last year’s journey is that there are so many sources of support out there to help us learn new things - what feels impossible is actually doable! One step at a time…

I’ll be repeating this like a mantra for my next challenge: building my website!

D A Y  4: Art book(s) 📚

My current obsessions are these 19th Century ‘encyclopaedias of ornamentation’!

They are filled with stunning reproductions of illustrated plates from artist designers including Owen Jones, Albert Racinet, Heinrich Dolmetsch, Alexander Speltz, F.M. Hessemer, and others, and I can’t get enough of them! 

Swipe ➡️ to see my bookshelf with my collection of titles, sourced second hand, and swipe again to see them horizontally, so they’re easier to read!

I’m using the books as inspiration for my set of online geometry courses on Geometric Church Pavements. 

Last year we looked at the pavements of Venice (check out the AMAZING student work on the hashtag #geometricchurchpavements) and in May this year we’ll be studying and drawing the #Cosmati pavements of Rome. I am so excited! 

If you’re interested, the link with further information is in my bio @clarissagrandi.art 🔗👈

D A Y  8: Inspiration💡

I think today’s stitched painting encapsulates some of the main sources of my inspiration: mathematical elegance and the beauty of nature’s forms.

I think I’m drawn to the gentle elegance of line and form in the natural world, and I love how this contrasts and interacts with the proportional harmonies inherent in geometric structures. There’s something about the interplay of symmetry and asymmetry, order and chaos, rigidity and freedom that, for me, hints at a truth held just out of reach.

I’m also interested in learning more about certain Japanese aesthetic principles, and applying them to my work. 

These principles include Kanzo (簡素) - simplicity and elimination of the non-essential; Fukinsei (不均整) - asymmetry or irregularity; and Shibumi (渋み) - understated elegance. 

It’s only recently that I’ve come across these concepts, and I’m really drawn to them. I think they put into words something I’ve been unconsciously trying to achieve with my work all along. 

I’m keen to learn more, and will endeavour to keep these ideals at the forefront of my mind in my art practice.

D A Y  11: Turning point ↩️

A huge turning point for me was the creation of my first online Zoom course in August 2020: the Introduction to Geometric Art (ITGA) course.

I’ve now delivered ITGA six times! And I’m running it again this February. Places are still available...

Swipe ➡️ to see just some of the patterns I teach on the course, which also includes tutorials on using fineliner pens and watercolour paints.

I have since created many other live online courses: Circles, Botanical Mandalas, Golden Geometry, Spirals and Labyrinths, Medieval Church Geometry and Geometric Church Pavements! 

And I’m also so grateful to be involved in exciting collaborations with other amazing geometric artists and teachers. 

To be able to put my secondary school maths teaching experience to use in creating and teaching geometric art courses was something I would never have foreseen a few years ago. 

It’s so wonderful to see a way forward to support myself through my art 🙏

If you’re interested in learning more about this super accessible art form, you can sign up to my newsletter and see my current course offerings via the links in my bio @clarissagrandi.art 👈🔗

D A Y  12: Current motif ⚛️

Recently, I have often found myself working with the ‘torus’ motif.

From Roman and Byzantine mosaics to Medieval floor tilings, these circular designs, built from layers of overlapping circles, crop up everywhere! 

I particularly enjoyed drawing this pattern of interlocking, double seed of life toruses, designed by @theartofprocess, and found in her @geometherapy book: #MasteringTheArtOfSix. 

Swipe ➡️ to see it gleam from different angles 🌿🌟

D A Y  14: Sold! 🔴

I haven’t sold any work for aaaaages - it’s hasn’t really been a focus of mine over the past year. 

So this is a throwback reel of a little #sketchbooktour I did after the #GeometrySketchbook hashtag challenge I completed for #SketchADayJune 2021.

D A Y  15 : How I name my paintings 🖼️

I must confess, I often take the ‘say what you see’ approach! 

For example, these paintings are from my first 100 Day project, #100DaysOfCircleGeometry, where I just went with one-word titles. 

Left to right and top to bottom, we have 
1. Path
2. Dusk
3. Shell
4. Orbit

Names often occurred to me while working on the paintings themselves - something would just pop into my head. 

It might be that the painting reminded me of something visually, or that I felt it was symbolic in some way.

Swipe to see the full set of 100! 

What was useful about needing to name 100 paintings in 100 days was that I didn’t have time to agonise or change my mind! 

And that helped my confidence with the process over time. 

How do you name your paintings?

D A Y  16: Smallest painting 🔍

My smallest paintings were created for my first 100 Days project, #100DaysOfCircleGeometry. 

Each one is enclosed in a 6.5cm diameter circle. 

It was during this project that I first started experimenting with stitching paper - a technique I have totally fallen in love with! 🪡💙🧵

It’s so calming and meditative to do, and it adds a textural, 3D element to artworks on paper. 

If you would like to try geometric paper embroidery, I have two Skillshare classes teaching the technique 🪡🧵

The links in my bio give you a free month to try out Skillshare and take my classes for free :) 

Just remember to cancel your subscription before the month is up, if you don’t want to stay (although you might find you do - Skillshare is great!)

D A Y  1 7: Largest painting ⛰️

My largest paintings were created for my  #100DaysExploringProcess project. 

This is a close up of one of the mixed media pieces (35 x 70cm) (swipe ➡️ to see more pics).

I used the challenge as an opportunity to try out working on a much larger scale, as well as investigating new substrates and art materials.

This piece means a great deal to me. I learnt so many new skills in the making of it: 
-how to stretch watercolour paper on stretcher bars, 
-how to use gold leaf size (glue) in a compass with a ruling pen, 
-how to plan and execute a large expanse of geometric hand stitching, 
-and how to frame a painting on canvas. 

At that point in time, it was the biggest painting l’d ever tackled, and I’m so pleased with how it turned out!

The stitched Asanoha pattern adds a delicate, tactile element to the painting - it’s as if you feel the piece, as well as see it. 

And the gilded seed of life is so shiny! I also enjoy how the Asanoha pattern escapes the confines of the seed of life, breaking out from its starting point.

Check out the #100DaysExploringProcess hashtag to see more of my process documented.
